Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The role of demographic stochasticity in community assembly
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the great puzzles in ecology is explaining how similar species can coexist in a community; presumably, one species should be a better competitor and cause extinction of all similar species. Plant coexistence is especially difficult to explain, because plants share a relatively small number of limiting resources, which should greatly restrict the number of species that can coexist. So, how it is possible for some plant communities to have hundreds of coexisting species? At least two factors, in addition to the number of limiting resources, might promote coexistence: conditions such as soil nutrient availability might vary within a community (environmental heterogeneity) and individual plants might have different rates of germination and death due to random chance (demographic stochasticity). Dr. Burns and her collaborators will conduct a novel experiment at Case Western Reserve University to ask: what is the relative importance of environmental heterogeneity and demographic stochasticity in creating conditions that allow for many species of plants to coexist? The proposed experiment will manipulate heterogeneity of the soil environment and introduce species into populations belonging to the same species and a closely related species. This experiment will be able to clearly distinguish for the first time the relative importance of environmental heterogeneity and demographic stochasticity in determining which species can be found together in a particular community.

Dr. Burns and her collaborators work closely with a local government organization, Cleveland Metroparks, to answer important local management questions and ensure open communication between scientists and land managers. Cleveland Metroparks is an ~8000 ha series of parks that ring the greater Cleveland area. The Cleveland Metroparks Natural Resources Division is committed to maintaining the health and diversity of the parks. Maintaining plant community diversity is essential for Metropark's ability to provide essential ecosystem services, such as providing clean water to the Cleveland area. This project will enhance our understanding of coexistence, and will help managers prevent and control biological invasions and maintain plant community diversity. For example, if more heterogeneous sites are more likely to be invaded by pest species, managers can target those areas for monitoring to prevent new and potentially detrimental biological invasions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Why are some communities highly diverse, and while others have few species? Why are some restoration attempts successful in restoring native diversity, while others fail? For plant communities, interactions between plants and soil microbes may be especially important for answering these questions. For example, farmers have long known that crops may accumulate species-specific pathogens in the soil, and thus crop rotations can help decrease disease and enhance yield. For native plant species, previous experiments have demonstrated that plants frequently change the microbial community in the soil root zone, influencing the next plant grown in that soil patch. These experiments often predict that "plant-soil feedbacks" should enhance plant coexistence, but connections between plant-soil feedbacks and their consequences for community diversity are still not fully understood.

In natural plant communities, the patchy (heterogeneous) and highly diverse nature of soil microbial communities is both a technical challenge and an opportunity for identifying the role of heterogeneity in structuring plant communities. This project included the development of a novel experimental technique: creating experimental soil patches generated by plant-soil feedbacks. Demographic measures such as germination, growth, and survival were quantified to determine how experimental soil patches might influence plant populations.

This project demonstrated that soils that are more heterogeneous enhance plant establishment, influence the expression of plant traits, and lead to a greater chance of coexistence between plant species (Fig. 1). Differences between experimental soils in bacterial and fungal community composition are consistent with a role of soil microbes in governing these plant responses.

The results of these experiments suggest the spatial arrangement of restoration plantings can be used to enhance coexistence and diversity. On the other hand, techniques that homogenize the soil, such as tilling, could reduce diversity. Maintaining or restoring native plant community diversity provides important ecosystem services, such as carbon sequestration and water filtering and retention. Maintaining these ecosystem services is an increasing challenge as factors such as land use change and biological invasions alter our natural systems. Research such as this may enhance such desirable restoration outcomes.

Broader outcomes

This work provided professional development and training for one postdoctoral scholar, three graduate students, thirteen undergraduate researchers, two visiting scholars, and one high school researcher. Poster presentations by undergraduate and high school students provided professional experiences and training for these students. Several undergraduate students have gone on to graduate school.

The results of this work have been shared broadly with the scientific community. This work resulted in invitations to two symposia (2012, 2016) and an organized oral session (2015) at the annual Ecological Society of America (ESA) conference and four contributed talks at ESA.

This work was also broadly disseminated via a Holden Scientists Lecture Series seminar in 2013, a Science Cafe presentation in 2014, and a nationally broadcast NPR interview in 2014.

 

Data from this project is archived at: Burns, J.H. & Brandt, A.J. (2014) Dryad Digital Repository, doi: 10.5061/dryad.gj7hb.
